text: hi everyone
Anthony Fantana here internet stuffiest
music nerd and it's time for a review
the men open up you open up a little bit
of the men are in New York band who I
reviewed last year when they made their
sacred bones Records debut with the
album leave home and the album had some
great tracks on it but it didn't end up
being one of my favorites of the year
for a couple reasons
for one the album didn't really have one
consistent style or sound it felt
stretched a little too thin because
there was never really one angle they
kept attacking so I never really felt
like I got to know the band all that
well I got to know their influences
though the band would trip through the
sounds of noise rock and post-hardcore
and maybe even a little doom metal and
punk garage rock psychedelic rock as
well it's like the band had all these
chips and they just kind of let them
fall where they may instead of kind of
playing them strategically the men
seemed too in love with the world of
rock music to just settle down with one
single sound and like I thought this new
album displays an array of different
styles of music on it they even managed
to toy with a few sounds I'm yet to hear
them play with there are moments on here
that just are rowdy garage rock with
just a tinge of Blues in there country
music drone acoustic ballads indie rock
ballads instrumental jams stylistically
the band is all over the place again but
I can't help but feel like this time
around they went into this album with a
much clearer game plan like if they were
going to play with as many styles as as
they wanted to they were at least going
to organize them make them so that they
didn't feel like they were in
disarray segue some of the tracks into
one another put the songs that are
stylistically similar closer to each
other so the album has a bit more of a
flow the album opens up with these
garage punk songs that I told you about
with these kicker guitar riffs and
these baby girl lyrics the guitar riffs
are all fuzzy and distorted and and
damaged and over driven in lo-fi and
just badass it sounds like they're being
played out of amplifiers that are on the
fritz like I'm seeing the band live and
their amplifiers are just catching on
fire because of hot and cold tubes and
bad wiring it sounds a little generic
but the band delivers it with enough
energy to the point where it's it's
pretty entertaining the second track is
is the same way for me except there's a
little bit more of a blues edge in that
track it's got a very country and rootsy
feel to it a little bit the song sounds
like what would sound track a southern
bar fight where beer bottles and pool
cues and stools are our weapons and
bodies are flying in every direction
smashing tables getting thrown out of
windows but right after that the album
kind of chills out into this very slow
and pretty and guitar led country
instrumental which eventually slides
into this guitar drone using the same
tremolo effects that were making the
song feel so country right at the
beginning and it does this transition
pretty well and an even better
transition is is right after that it
uses the tremolo effect to bring things
into the next track where the BAM pretty
much creates a guitar rock jam that is
pulled straight out of the NOI playbook
very kind of krautrock esque but it's
got some really modern punked-out guts
to it I mean the segues on this LP
really make this thing feel like more of
a journey more of an adventure the indie
rock tune that breaks in right after
this Jam kind of feels like an extension
of that song and then after this the
band kind of settles into a sweet spot
with a trio of a very short and cat
she tracks I feel like the band kind of
breaks off stylistically at this point
the album kind of loses its flow of it
but the band churns out three of the
most memorable songs that ever heard
them rice so I'm really okay with it the
LP ends with some solid jams and I feel
like this album a lot like that Cloud
Nothings album that came out earlier
this year I just get kind of a really
solid rock record that's memorable it's
catchy fun enjoyable and just difficult
to say no to even if it is a little
derivative because the energy is most
certainly there and the energy and the
passion is really what's attracting me
to these songs feeling a strong seven on
this LP I feel like it's a huge
improvement over leave home
overall yeah it's a little less
aggressive less noisy less abrasive and
that may have attracted some people to
the men originally there may be some
fans that are disappointed to see those
sounds kind of move away but I thought
this LP had a much better flow some
really nice catchy and positive vibes
coming off some of these tracks and I
don't know just overall it was a more
enjoyable experience for me I just came
away from this album wanting more
whining repeat listens and just really
looking forward to what these guys do
after this so let me know what do you
think of this thing do you love it do
you hate it well why and what do you
think I should review after this anthony
Fantan oh the men forever
